title: Will computers replace mathematicians in coming decades? - Quora

response.answer_text: The language of mathematics is huge. There's an unlimited quantity of mathematics yet to be developed.   Even so, computer programs can be written to eventually spew it all out. Such a program would, however, spew out the bad with the good, and there's a lot more bad than good.  What's bad mathematics?  Anything that's uninteresting, and the uninteresting kind far outweighs the interesting kind.   For example, write down any complicated function at random.  Let it involve trig functions, logs, exponents, roots, composition, etc.  It's almost certainly uninteresting.  Although symbolic integrators might be able to give you its integral, that will be even more uninteresting.    What determines what's interesting?  In part, that's a matter of personal taste, but there are some common themes.  If the mathematics can be applied to science or other parts of mathematics, it can be interesting.  If it's a question people have looked at for a long time, it's interesting.  If it's something new, but when you show it to mathematicians and they consider it interesting, then it is. Can a computer program tell what's interesting math?  That's a question for the experts in Artificial Intelligence.  If you let the decades keep on coming, then the answer might eventually be yes.

I don't think so. In a very meta-circular way, my reasoning for this depends on what might be the most important open question in mathematics and computer science. Does P=NP? I won't necessarily go into too much detail here because it's covered so many other places but the implications of P=NP are huge. Effectively, any problem to which a computer can recognize a correct answer "quickly" belongs to the set of NP problems. Any problem that a computer can actually generate a solution to very quickly is a member of the set P. Proofs to mathematical theorems are the primary creation  of mathematicians and these problems belong to the set NP. Once a mathematician has given me a proof of a theorem, I can easily verify that it is true, possibly with the help of a computer, in a very short amount of time. Creating said proof, however, requires an amount of creativity that has alluded computers. If P=NP these proofs could be generated in an automated way which would likely put mathematicians completely out of business. I don't, however, think that this will ever happen because the vast majority of people who have studied the topic believe that N does not equal NP.

I think this question is based on a false premise, namely that mathematics is mere mechanical thinking, deriving conclusions from a set of premises in strictly logical, mechanical way by applying a set of fixed rules over and over again. In other words, if you would reduce mathematics to calculations, then the answer could probably be yes. However, mathematics is much more than this. Mathematics is a creative act, created by humans and progress in mathematics is made by creative human who come up with novel solutions by a trial-and-error process. This aspect of mathematics would be very hard, if not impossible to replace with computers. I don't know what will happen in the very long term, but I don't see AI replacing this kind of intelligence within the next 30 years. The importance of computers in mathematics will almost certainly increase, but they will not replace the human factor.

No. Not at all. Maybe you are confused with what mathematicians do. If you think that mathematicians spend their days evaluating integrals, determining derivatives, calculating sums, products or differences, and solve equations, you are wrong. Those are things that a computer can do, and we're glad that computers are taking over the tedious part of mathematics. The beautiful part of mathematics is the discovery and proofs of new theorems by synthesizing together other established results. Until a computer can start doing this effectively, it's safe to say that mathematicians will not be replaced by computers anytime soon.

Mathematics is more about insight and creative solutions than about following rules, while computers are all about following rules. Computers may learn to think creatively too, but they won't be an economically sensible replacement any time soon. I expect that computer aided proving will play a increasing role, but those provers don't work without a flesh and blood mathematician.

No more than they already have.Originally, the word 'computer' referred to a person, not a machine: see Human computer. This was a typical job for bright science students - the professors would hand them an expression too tedious for them to do themselves, and the computers job would be to, well, compute it.These jobs are obviously gone now, so no, computers will not replace mathematicians, but computers have already replaced (human) computers.
